repnme.cdata!: Mali - Building a better growth foundation

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            building a better growth foundation in Mali. Mali is a vast
            landlocked country located in the heart of the Sahel, a
            region threatened by drought and desertification. The vast
            majority of the people were directly dependent on the
            environment for their livelihoods through herding, farming,
            or fishing. The International Development Association
            supported Mali through various projects, in addressing its
            economic challenges with a focus on education, health,
            agriculture, and energy. The Fostering Agricultural
            Productivity Project improved productivity of targeted
            horticultural and livestock products and better access to
            markets, financing, and commercial infrastructure. Energy
            Support Project increased access to electricity through the
            interconnected network and promoted regional integration and
            energy diversification

repnme.cdata!: Mali - Second education sector investment program

abstracts.cdata!:
This results profile talks about the
            Second Education Sector Investment Program in Mali. The
            program is helping to increase access and quality of basic
            education. The ongoing program is progressing towards its
            development objective of education for all by 2020: access
            to primary education has reached 82 percent (gross
            enrollment rate); overall learning achievement is also
            improving from 54 percent to 55.7 percent. However, the
            gender enrollment gap in primary education is still signed
            with the differences of 18 percentage points between boys
            and girls. In addition, the project has reached 1,400,000
            students in primary school through direct transfers of funds
            to decentralized entities.

docna.cdata!:
Malí - Segundo programa de inversión en el
            sector educativo

repnme.cdata!:
Le système éducatif malien : Analyse
            sectorielle pour une amélioration de la qualité et de leffi
            cacité du système

abstracts.cdata!:
This report is the second Country Status
            Reports (CSR) for Mali and constitutes an update of the one
            prepared in 2005 which dealt with the improvement of access
            to education, the improvement of the quality of teaching and
            the building of the education systems capacities. While the
            second phase (PISE II), with the same key objectives, ended
            in December 2009, today, Mali is preparing the third phase
            of the Sector Program (2010-2012). It is in this context
            that this report has been prepared, complementing other
            thematic studies (management of the flow of pupils, training
            and deployment of teaching staff, decentralization of
            education, curricula) to propose a review of the status of
            the Malian education system and offer national
            decision-makers and their development partners a solid
            analytical basis to inform the political dialogue and the
            decision-making process. The report shows that demographic
            pressure is fairly high and represents a huge challenge for
            Malis education system. Further demographic pressure is
            fairly high and represents a huge challenge for Malis
            education system and enabled an increase in government
            resources while education has risen on the list of national
            priorities. External resources have also increased but
            intra-sector distribution of resources is not sufficiently
            in favor of primary education. Private expenditure on
            education represented 16 percent of all education
            expenditure in 2008 yet schooling coverage has greatly
            improved over recent years. However, school access is not
            yet universal and there is still a considerable amount of
            drop-out at all levels of education with drop-out and
            repetition contributing to the systems poor internal
            effectiveness. The quality of learning is poor and many
            children are already underachieving in the course of primary
            education. Moreover, there are considerable disparities in
            enrollments according to gender and place of residence but
            the households standard of living is the largest
            discriminatory factor in enrollments. The study added that
            75 percent of public resources allocated to education
            benefit the 20 percent wealthiest and the regional
            disparities are also high: the North is behind compared to
            the rest of the country. Unit costs in terms of GDP per
            capita have decreased at all levels of education, owing to
            enrollments increasing more rapidly than the budget.
            Student-teacher ratios are too high with considerable
            variability in the status of teaching personnel and their
            levels of salary. Government allocation of teachers and
            textbooks to schools is not sufficiently related to
            enrollments and pedagogical management is also poor and
            Incompatibility between education system leavers and the
            labor market is problematic.

Le système éducatif malien : Analyse

repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Additional Financing Credit for the
            Second Education Sector Investment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to provide Additional Financing for
            Phase II of the Education Investment Program (ESIP II or the
            Project), presently financed under IDA Credit 4222-MLI. The
            additional financing is required to complete the original
            project activities in view of a new financing gap that has
            emerged over the past year related to expected parallel
            financing for primary education. The original project
            development objective remains the same: to increase the
            proportion of Malian children completing a quality first
            cycle of basic education and improve the overall efficiency
            of resources used in the education sector. No changes to the
            components, key performance indicators, or implementation
            modalities of the project are being proposed. A one year
            extension of the closing date is proposed to allow for a
            full implementation of the project activities. The
            Project's original objective, design and scope remain unchanged.
